title: If formal sciences by definition do not exist in space-time, logically we could use two possibilities, they do not exist at all or exist outside the physical universe (Platonism), which position would be the most correct? - Quora

response.answer_text: Or that maybe ‘exist’ is a more complicated concept than it seems. Would you say that a rainbow exists? On the one hand, you can describe properties of it. On the other, it is different a different set of raindrops involved, if only minutely, for every single observer. And also for a single observer, second by second. Or, like the classics ‘Argo’ problem, in what sense does a football club exist, if you can change all the supporters, all the players and managers, and even which ground they play at? In short, although you say there are two possibilities, I don’t think that you have covered all the alternatives.
In order to be correct they would have to have some applicable meaning. Neither of these propositions has an applicable meaning.
